name: Brumer–Stark conjecture
summary: The Brumer–Stark conjecture is a conjecture in algebraic number theory that connects the special values of L-functions to the structure of ideal class groups. It states that a certain element called the Stickelberger element annihilates the relevant class group of an abelian extension of number fields. The conjecture is a key part of Stark's conjectures and has a deep connection to Hilbert's twelfth problem, which is the goal of constructing class fields explicitly.
head: \(H/F\) is a finite abelian extension of number fields (with \(F\) totally real and \(H\) a CM field), \(S\) and \(T\) are disjoint finite sets of places of \(F\) (containing all infinite places and ramified finite places) satisfying certain standard conditions, and \(\Theta _{H/F,S,T}\) is the associated Stickelberger element in the rational group ring \(\mathbb{Q}[Gal(H/F)]\),
